subject: History
title: Roman Engineering Marvels
description: A 60-second lesson on Roman Engineering Marvels.

hook.text: Roman concrete has lasted 2,000 years. Modern concrete crumbles in 50. We're still catching up.

buildup.text: Romans built 250,000 miles of roads, aqueducts spanning valleys, and the Pantheon's unsupported dome.

discovery.text: Their secret? Volcanic ash concrete that actually strengthens when exposed to seawater over time.

twist.text: Roman sewers were so advanced that the Cloaca Maxima in Rome still functions after 2,500 years.

climax.text: When Rome fell, Europe lost these engineering skills for a thousand years. The Dark Ages were literal.

punchline.text: Rome built infrastructure that outlived the empire.

quiz.question: What makes Roman concrete special compared to modern versions?
options: It uses heavier stones for better strength
Volcanic ash lets it strengthen with seawater over time
It was reinforced with iron bars
